metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with TerraSAR-X satellite overpassing in the Daman Superstation (June 15, 2012)
metadata.description:
On June 15, 2012, the satellite transit ground synchronous observation was carried out in the TerraSAR-X sample near the super station in the dense observation area of Daman. TerraSAR-X satellite carries X-band synthetic aperture radar (SAR). The daily transit image is HH / VV polarized, with a nominal resolution of 3 m, an incidence angle of 22-24 ° and a transit time of 19:03 (Beijing time), which mainly covers the ecological and hydrological experimental area of the middle reaches artificial oasis. The local synchronous data set can provide the basic ground data set for the development and verification of active microwave remote sensing soil moisture retrieval algorithm.            
Quadrat and sampling strategy:            
Six natural blocks are selected in the southeast of the super station, with an area of about 100 m × 100 m. One plot in the northwest corner of the sample plot is watermelon field, others are corn. The basis of sample selection is: (1) considering different vegetation types, i.e. watermelon and corn; (2) considering the visible light pixel, the sample size of 100m square can guarantee at least 4 30 M-pixel is located in the sample; (3) the location of the sample is near the super station, with convenient transportation. The observation of the super station is in the north, and there is a water net node on both sides of the East and the west, which makes it possible to integrate these observations in the future; (4) in addition, there are some obvious points around the sample, which can ensure that the geometric correction of the SAR image is more accurate in the future.            
Considering the resolution of the image, 21 splines (distributed from east to West) are collected at 5 m intervals. Each line has 23 points (north-south direction) at 5 m intervals. Four hydroprobe data acquisition systems (HDAS, reference 2) are used to measure at the same time. The sampling interval is controlled by the scale and moving splines on the measuring line to make up for the lack of using hand-held GPS.            
Measurement content:            
About 500 points on the quadrat were obtained, and each point was observed twice, i.e. in each sampling point, once in the film (marked a in the data record) and once out of the film (marked b in the data record); although the watermelon land was also covered with film, considering that it was not laid horizontally, only the soil moisture at the non covered position was measured (marked b in both data records). As the HDAS system uses pogo portable soil sensor, the soil temperature, soil moisture (volume moisture content), loss tangent, soil conductivity, real part and imaginary part of soil complex dielectric are observed. The vegetation team completed the measurement of biomass, Lai, vegetation water content, plant height, row ridge distance, chlorophyll, etc.            
Data:            
This data set includes two parts: soil moisture observation and vegetation observation. The former saves the data format as a vector file, the spatial location is the location of each sampling point (WGS84 + UTM 47N), and the measurement information of soil moisture is recorded in the attribute file; the vegetation sampling information is recorded in the excel table.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: What is an example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture and vegetation dynamics in an oasis-desert area?

Example.Answer: A dataset example that supports the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms is the collection of ground synchronous observations conducted near the TerraSAR-X satellite sample plots, which provide soil moisture information for algorithm validation in active microwave remote sensing.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial in eco-hydrological research as they address the challenge of upscaling processes on heterogeneous surfaces. They provide comprehensive data necessary for understanding and modeling eco-hydrological processes across different spatial and temporal scales, as exemplified by the instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales in HiWATER.

Definition.Question: What are the key features of a hierarchically nested observation system in eco-hydrological experiments?
Definition.Answer: A hierarchically nested observation system in eco-hydrological experiments is characterized by the arrangement of instruments at various scales, such as flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and interactions, as demonstrated in the HiWATER experiment.

Definition.Question: How is data quality control ensured in eco-hydrological experiments involving diverse data sources?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control in eco-hydrological experiments with diverse data sources, such as HiWATER, is ensured through meticulous sensor calibration, systematic data collection, careful data processing, and rigorous dataset generation procedures, ensuring the reliability and accuracy of the multiscale datasets.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used at the superstation within the oasis compare to those used in the surrounding landscapes such as sandy desert, desert pavement, and wetland?
Comparison.Answer: The superstation within the oasis utilized a combination of eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and intensive observation periods, while the surrounding landscapes were equipped with four EC towers and two-layer automatic meteorological stations to capture the unique eco-hydrological processes of each area. The methods were hierarchically nested to monitor different scales of eco-hydrological interactions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the types of data collected by the TerraSAR-X satellite observations and the HiWATER airborne remote sensing missions?
Comparison.Answer: The TerraSAR-X satellite observations focused on obtaining high-resolution SAR imagery with HH/VV polarization for soil moisture inversion. In contrast, the HiWATER airborne missions utilized a variety of instruments, including LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and an L-band microwave radiometer, to collect multiscale data covering a wide range of eco-hydrological parameters.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of collecting multiscale observations in the HiWATER experiment compare to the challenges faced in the TerraSAR-X ground-synchronous observations?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment faced challenges related to the poor availability of multiscale observations and the need for hierarchical instrumentation to study heterogeneous surfaces. Meanwhile, the TerraSAR-X ground-synchronous observations specifically dealt with geometric correction and achieving adequate sampling density, requiring strategic placement of sample plots and synchronization with satellite overpasses.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a grand challenge for upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to establish a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions in data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A sparse network is necessary to investigate the oasis-desert interaction because it allows for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, which are crucial for understanding the dynamics between different landscapes such as sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for hierarchical instrumentation in capturing eco-hydrological data across different scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Hierarchical instrumentation is required to capture eco-hydrological data across different scales because it helps obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data, addressing the challenge of poor availability of such observations in heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of multiscale observations impact the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of multiscale observations, such as those from the HiWATER experiment, provides essential ground data that support the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms. These observations help address the challenge of scaling up eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces by offering detailed insights at various scales, from local to regional.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of deploying a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup on the understanding of oasis-desert eco-hydrological interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Deploying a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup, as done in the HiWATER experiment, allows for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, leading to a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions. This setup helps in gathering comprehensive data across different landscapes and scales, which is crucial for studying how these interactions affect water and energy exchanges in such regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose behind utilizing hierarchically nested scales for data collection in eco-hydrological studies in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, which is a challenge due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. By using hierarchically nested scales, researchers can obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data to better understand these processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to carry out intensive observation periods (IOPs) along with continuous hydrometeorological observations within the HiWATER project?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The importance lies in addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations. Intensive observation periods, combined with continuous observations, allow researchers to gather detailed and comprehensive data across different temporal and spatial scales, enabling a better investigation of eco-hydrological processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are diverse ecological and hydrological parameters integrated into a cohesive dataset for multiscale analysis in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments are deployed at hierarchically nested scales, including eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and a sparse network in different landscapes to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. These observations are complemented by ground measurements and remote sensing missions, all of which are systematically calibrated and quality-controlled before data integration.

Enablement.Question: How do multiscale observations enable the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Multiscale observations enable understanding by employing a hierarchical setup of instruments, including eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, to capture diverse data across various landscape scales and processes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary to enable effective data collection during intensive observation periods for eco-hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: Effective data collection during intensive observation periods is enabled by strategic placement of instruments in hierarchically nested scales, comprehensive sensor networks, and synchronical ground measurements, ensuring data quality control from sensor calibration to data processing.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observations be limited in capturing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, as comprehensive data collection at multiple scales is challenging and requires hierarchically nested instrumentation.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the challenges faced in developing soil moisture algorithms using active microwave remote sensing methods?
Expectation.Answer: Developing and validating soil moisture algorithms with active microwave remote sensing methods face challenges due to the need for basic ground datasets, such as those provided by synchronized ground observations, which are essential for accurate retrieval but are often limited in availability.

Judgmental.Question: How might the hierarchical arrangement of instruments contribute to the effectiveness of data collection in eco-hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The hierarchical arrangement of instruments is designed to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, which can significantly enhance the effectiveness of data collection. By situating instruments like eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations at different scales and landscapes, researchers can obtain a comprehensive understanding of the interactions between various ecological and hydrological processes within the oasis-desert system.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One major challenge in collecting multiscale observations is the poor availability of such data, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes. To address this, HiWATER designed an experiment that utilizes a network of hierarchically nested instruments and intensive observation periods. This approach allows for the collection of diverse and high-quality data across different scales, which can be used to better understand and model eco-hydrological interactions.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the synchronization of satellite imagery with ground observations enhance the development of soil moisture algorithms?
Judgmental.Answer: Synchronizing satellite imagery with ground observations can provide essential data for developing and validating soil moisture algorithms. By aligning TerraSAR-X satellite passes with ground data collection, researchers can obtain accurate, real-time information on soil conditions, which is critical for improving the precision of remote sensing algorithms. This synergy between satellite and ground data enables more reliable predictions and assessments of soil moisture levels across different terrains.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges associated with the availability of multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges associated with the availability of multiscale observations is the poor availability of these data, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes. The HiWATER experiment attempts to address this challenge by providing a multiscale and multidisciplinary dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used in eco-hydrological studies to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer are utilized, along with synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please conduct a search for potential datasets related to eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas and compare their availability and data quality control measures.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets related to eco-hydrological processes include those obtained from the HiWATER experiment, which are available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre. These datasets are multiscale and have been carefully quality controlled through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation.
